questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read 2 Samuel 1:1-18 aloud, paying attention to the messenger's description of Saul's condition and the emotional response of David.
tips: Notice the messenger's description: 'torn clothes and dust on his head' (v1)
Pay attention to David's response: 'tear their clothes, mourn, weep, and fast until evening' (v2-3)
Listen for the emotional weight in the lament: 'How the mighty have fallen!' (v16)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (David and the messenger), WHAT (learning of Saul's death), WHERE (Ziklag), and WHY (Saul was killed by an Amalekite).
tips: Include the messenger's report that Saul was killed by an Amalekite (v1)
Note David's mourning for Saul and Jonathan (v2-3)
Describe the Amalekite's confession and David's execution of the murderer (v4-6)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the messenger's account (v1), David's mourning (v2-3), or the lament (v16-27).
tips: The lament: 'How the mighty have fallen!' (v16) - a powerful contrast between the mighty (Saul) and the fall
David's love for Jonathan: 'your love was extraordinary, surpassing the love of women' (v17) - shows deep emotional connection
The messenger's account: 'Saul, wounded by archers and about to be overtaken' (v1) - highlights the tragedy

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was the author (Samuel/Nathan/Gad) trying to communicate to Israel about the consequences of the death of God's anointed king?
tips: The author shows that even the most powerful (Saul) can be overthrown by God's will
David's mourning for his enemy (Saul) demonstrates the cost of sin and the value of loyalty to God's anointed
This passage foreshadows Christ's death and the mourning that comes with the cross (as in Christ weeping over Jerusalem)

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The Amalekite's confession, the execution of the murderer, or the depth of David's mourning for his enemy?
tips: The Amalekite's confession: he killed Saul, who was the LORD's anointed (v4) - in the context, this was a grave sin because Saul was God's chosen leader
David's mourning for Saul (an enemy) - this was unusual because Saul had been David's enemy (v1-2)
The cultural context: mourning for a king was a public act, but David mourned for his enemy (Saul) and his close friend (Jonathan)

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you practice deep mourning and love for those who have been wronged by circumstances, even if they are enemies, this week?
tips: This week, when you face a loss or a situation where someone has been wronged, practice mourning (like David) without blame
Think about how you can show love for those who have been affected by circumstances, even if they are enemies
Practice 'fasting and weeping' (v2-3) for a brief time to express your grief

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray: Thank God for the love that transcends enmity. Ask for courage to mourn the consequences of sin and to show love for those who have been wronged by God's will.
tips: Thank God for the love that transcends enmity (like David's love for Saul)
Pray for courage to mourn the consequences of sin and to show love for those who have been wronged by God's will
Ask God to help you understand the depth of David's grief and to share it with others

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read 2 Samuel 3:1-39 aloud, focusing on the tension between Abner's loyalty to Saul and his conflict with Ishbosheth.
tips: Notice the phrase 'I show loyalty to Saul's house' (v. 11) - Abner's declaration of loyalty
Pay attention to the emotional shift when Abner stabs Joab (v. 28-30) - the sudden violence after the peace
Listen for the repetition of 'David' (v. 10, 15, 21) as the central figure in the kingdom transition

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: Summarize who, what, where, and why in the events of 2 Samuel 3, focusing on the key players and their actions.
tips: Include Abner's vow to transfer the kingdom to David (v. 10)
Note the return of Michal from her weeping husband (v. 14-15)
Describe Joab's revenge for Asahel and the murder of Abner (v. 28-30)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: Abner's vow to transfer the kingdom (v. 10), the return of Michal (v. 14-15), or Joab's murder of Abner (v. 28-30)?
tips: Abner's declaration: 'I will bring the kingdom to David as the LORD swore' (v. 10) - shows his commitment to God's promise
The emotional weight of Michal being taken from her weeping husband (v. 15) - David's sacrifice for his wife
The shocking violence of Joab's murder at the gate (v. 28-30) - the immediate revenge that breaks the peace

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was the author (Samuel/Nathan/Gad) trying to communicate about the cost of loyalty and the pursuit of peace to the Israelites?
tips: The passage shows that true loyalty to God's kingdom requires sacrifice (like David's purchase of Michal with 100 foreskins)
The contrast between Abner's peaceful covenant and Joab's treachery highlights the danger of blood revenge
This event foreshadows Christ's ultimate sacrifice where peace is made without treachery

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging to understand in this chapter? Consider cultural context, terminology, or theological concepts.
tips: The term 'concubine' (v. 11) - in ancient Israel, concubines were secondary wives, but here Rizpah is specifically Saul's concubine
The blood revenge (v. 28-30) - in the context of the time, revenge was common but Abner's murder was done without the king's authority, making it treacherous
The phrase 'David's house' (v. 10) - the author uses this to mean David's lineage and rule, not just the person

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you avoid the treachery of Joab and seek peace in your relationships this week, as modeled by David's leadership?
tips: Reflect on a situation where you have a 'Michal' (someone precious) that needs your care
Consider how you can forgive without revenge, like David's public mourning for Abner
Pray for the strength to choose peace over blood revenge, as Christ did

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray for the peace that David sought and the avoidance of treachery in your life.
tips: Thank God for the peace David made with Abner before the murder
Ask for courage to forgive like David did for Joab
Pray that you will not fall into the trap of blood revenge as Joab did

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read 2 Samuel 4:1-18 aloud, focusing on the emotional shift from Ishbosheth's despair to the assassins' actions and David's decisive response.
tips: Notice the phrase 'when he was lying down' (v.1) shows vulnerability
Pay attention to the contrast between 'midday heat' (v.11) and the swift execution
The phrase 'how much more' (v.16) reveals David's moral outrage

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (Ishbosheth, Rechab, Baanah, David) does WHAT (assassination of Ishbosheth and David's response), WHERE (Ishbosheth's house, Hebron), and WHY (because the assassins killed a righteous man in his own house).
tips: Include that the assassins traveled all night to David at Hebron (v.14)
Note that David orders the execution of the assassins (v.17)
Mention that Ishbosheth's head is buried in Abner's tomb (v.18)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stands out most? Consider: David's words about 'wicked men killing a righteous man' (v.16), the assassins' quick action (v.11-12), or David's order for the assassins' execution (v.17)?
tips: David's statement 'how much more' (v.16) shows his moral clarity about murder and justice
The assassins acting in the midday heat (v.11) highlights the brutality and haste
David's immediate response to the head (v.15) shows his commitment to justice

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was the author (Samuel/Nathan/Gad) trying to communicate to Israel about God's rule and justice?
tips: The passage shows that God's kingdom is established through righteous leadership, not violence
David's refusal to benefit from murder (v.16) sets a standard for justice in God's kingdom
This event foreshadows Christ's refusal to benefit from sin and His own sacrifice

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are confusing? The assassins' motivation, why David's response is so severe, and the burial of Ishbosheth in Abner's tomb?
tips: Why did the assassins kill Ishbosheth? The text doesn't say, but it was likely revenge for Abner's death (v.10)
David's response: He didn't hesitate to execute the assassins even though they were his enemies' killers (v.16)
Burial in Abner's tomb (v.18) shows that David honors the dead, even his enemy's killer

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How does David's refusal to benefit from murder (v.16) challenge us to live justly in our own lives?
tips: When you are tempted to take revenge for a wrong, ask: 'How much more would David do?'
Pray that you would be willing to let go of your anger and seek justice through God
This week, choose one person you've been holding a grudge against and practice forgiveness

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray about David's commitment to justice and his refusal to benefit from murder.
tips: Thank God for David's example of justice in the face of murder
Pray for courage to forgive when we are wronged
Ask God to help us see the cost of revenge and choose justice over vengeance

chapters.chapterTitle: David King over All Israel; Jerusalem Conquered

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read 2 Samuel 5:1-25 aloud, focusing on the dialogue and actions when David conquers Jerusalem and the Philistine battle.
tips: Notice the phrase 'the blind and lame will turn you back' (v. 8) as a challenge from the Jebusites
Pay attention to David's strategy of entering through the water shaft (v. 9)
Listen for the description of the Philistine battle from Geba to Gezer (v. 22)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: Summarize WHO is involved, WHAT happens, WHERE it takes place, and WHY it matters for David's reign.
tips: Include the tribes coming to David at Hebron (v. 1-3)
Note David's conquest of Jerusalem (v. 6-9) and building the city (v. 10-11)
Describe the Philistine battle (v. 18-25)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: David's conquest of Jerusalem, the water shaft, or the Philistine battle?
tips: David's clever move of entering through the water shaft shows his resourcefulness and God's favor (v. 9)
The Jebusites' mocking phrase 'the blind and lame will turn you back' (v. 8) highlights the challenge David faced
David's victory over the Philistines from Geba to Gezer demonstrates God's protection (v. 22)

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was the author (Samuel/Nathan/Gad) trying to communicate to Israel about David's kingship and Jerusalem?
tips: This passage shows that God has chosen David to rule over all Israel, fulfilling His promise (v. 3)
The establishment of Jerusalem as David's city signifies God's presence with His people
David's house (palace) being built by Hiram's gifts (v. 12-14) points to God's provision for His king

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging to understand in this chapter?
tips: The Jebusites were the original inhabitants of Jerusalem (v. 6-9) - why did they mock David? (they were a powerful group)
The water shaft is a hidden passage used for entry - how did David know about it? (it's a strategic detail)
David taking more wives and concubines (v. 15-17) - how does this fit with the theme of God's kingdom? (it shows the human side of David's rule)

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the theme of God's provision in establishing a city for His people to your life this week?
tips: Think about a place in your life that needs to be 'built up' like Jerusalem (e.g., a relationship, community, or purpose)
Practice the resourcefulness of David by finding creative solutions for challenges (like the water shaft)
Pray for God's guidance when facing opposition (like the Philistines) to overcome obstacles

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together about God's establishment of His kingdom through David and Jerusalem.
tips: Thank God for His faithfulness to David and for the city of Jerusalem as a symbol of His people
Ask for courage to be a 'David' in your life, taking steps to build up God's kingdom
Pray for the protection of the church (as the new Jerusalem) from opposition

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read 2 Samuel 6:1-23 aloud, paying attention to the tension between celebration and divine judgment.
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'the ark of the covenant' (v.2, 4, 5, 7)
Pay attention to the emotional shift from joy (v.1-5) to horror (v.10-11) and then to David's joy (v.16-18)
Listen for the contrast between David's dancing and Michal's contempt (v.16-23)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (David, Uzzah, Ahio, Obed-edom, Israel), WHAT (bringing the ark to Jerusalem), WHERE (from Baale-judah to the threshing floor of Nacon, then to Obed-edom's house), and WHY (to set up the ark in the city of David for worship).
tips: Include the three-day journey to Jerusalem (v.1-5)
Note Uzzah's death at the threshing floor of Nacon (v.10-11)
Describe David's decision to leave the ark at Obed-edom's house for three months (v.1-11)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: Identify the most impactful event, person, or dialogue from 2 Samuel 6:1-23.
tips: The ark's journey to Jerusalem and its significance
Uzzah's death as a consequence of human error
David's response to the ark's arrival and his leadership

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: David worshiped with joy and abandon. What situation requires you to worship God with joy and abandon this week?
tips: When you feel the need to approach God with fear or shame, practice worship with joy
Surrender a small area of your life (e.g., a worry, a habit) to God with joyful abandon
Practice dancing in your heart (v.16-18) by expressing your joy to God without reservation

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for His presence and ask for the courage to worship Him with joy and abandon.
tips: Thank God for the blessing of His presence in your life (like the ark in Obed-edom's house)
Ask God to remove the presumption that leads to spiritual death (like Uzzah)
Pray for the strength to worship Him with joy and abandon, as David did

tips: Be specific and practical
Think about this week

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read 2 Samuel 9:1-13 aloud, paying attention to Mephibosheth's humility in verse 4 and David's repeated promise of kindness in verses 2 and 12.
tips: Notice the phrase 'behold, your servant' (v. 4) - shows deep humility
Pay attention to the repeated phrase 'I will show you kindness' (v. 2, 12) - emphasizes covenantal promise
Observe the contrast between Mephibosheth's physical condition (lame in both feet) and his restored status (eating at the king's table)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO David shows kindness to, WHAT he does, WHERE it happens, and WHY he does it (for Jonathan's sake).
tips: Include Mephibosheth (Jonathan's son, lame in both feet) as the recipient
Note David's restoration of Saul's land and table fellowship with the king
Mention Ziba's role as the servant who reports and later manages the land for Mephibosheth

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider Mephibosheth's humility (v. 4), David's promise (v. 2, 12), or the restoration of land (v. 12).
tips: Mephibosheth's response: 'what is your servant that you notice a dead dog like me?' shows his low self-perception and humility
David's promise: 'I will restore all Saul's land' and 'you will always eat at my table' is a profound act of covenantal kindness
The detail of Ziba's household serving Mephibosheth (v. 12) shows the practical restoration of the covenant

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was the author (Samuel/Nathan/Gad) trying to communicate to Israel about God's character and covenant through David's kindness to Mephibosheth?
tips: This passage shows God's faithfulness to covenant promises (David as king) even when the king's family is in trouble
It emphasizes that kindness is not conditional on merit but on the covenant relationship (Jonathan's faithfulness to David)
The restoration of land and table fellowship points to the future restoration of Israel under God's rule

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The role of Ziba, the meaning of 'dead dog', or why David restores Saul's land?
tips: Ziba: He was Saul's servant who took care of Mephibosheth's household. In some contexts, servants were not considered part of the lineage, but here David restores the land to Ziba's household to maint
'Dead dog': This is a lowly, unclean animal in ancient Israel. Mephibosheth is comparing himself to this, showing his humility and low status (he was lame and had no standing)
Why restore Saul's land? David is restoring the land to the family of Saul (Mephibosheth) to show that God's covenant with Saul (through Jonathan) is maintained even after Saul's death

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you practice the kindness of David toward Mephibosheth in your life this week?
tips: Consider someone who is marginalized or in a low status and offer them a blessing or restoration of their dignity
Think about what you can do to restore a relationship or provide for someone who has been overlooked (like the land for Mephibosheth)

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for His kindness to the humble and ask for the courage to show kindness to others.
tips: Thank God for restoring the broken (like Mephibosheth) through Christ
Ask for the strength to be like David and show kindness to those who are lowly or in need
Pray for the church to be a place of table fellowship (community) for the marginalized

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read 2 Samuel 10:1-19 aloud, paying attention to the contrast between David's initial kindness and the harsh treatment of his servants.
tips: Notice the contrast between David's initial kindness (v.2) and the harsh treatment of his servants (v.4-5)
Pay attention to the emotional tone in Hanun's decision to seize the servants (v.4) and the humiliation (v.5)
The phrase 'half their beards' (v.5) is a significant mark of humiliation

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO does WHAT, WHERE, and WHY in this chapter.
tips: Include: David sends servants to express sympathy after the king of Ammon dies (v.2)
Note Hanun's advisers' accusation that David sent spies to overthrow him (v.4)
Describe the humiliation of David's servants (v.4-5) and the subsequent hiring of Aramean mercenaries (v.6)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider the humiliation of David's servants, the swift response of the Arameans, or the decisive victory of David's army.
tips: The phrase 'half their beards' (v.5) is a culturally specific humiliation that shows the depth of the insult
The immediate hiring of 33,000 Aramean mercenaries (v.6) highlights how quickly the Ammonites turned to their enemies
Joab's charge to be strong and let the LORD do what seems good (v.19) is a powerful reminder of trust in God

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Samuel/Nathan/Gad trying to communicate to Israel through this passage?
tips: This passage shows that good intentions can be misinterpreted, leading to consequences that require God's intervention
It emphasizes the importance of discernment and the consequences of misjudging others
The victory over the combined forces of Ammon and Aram demonstrates God's protection for His people when they trust Him

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? Consider cultural context, unfamiliar terms, or theological concepts.
tips: The term 'half their beards' (v.5) is a specific form of humiliation in ancient Near Eastern culture, indicating a loss of status and identity
The hiring of 33,000 Aramean mercenaries (v.6) shows the Ammonites' desperation but reflects complex regional alliances
The phrase 'the LORD do what seems good to Him' (v.19) is a key expression of trust in God's sovereignty, but may be challenging to apply in immediate situations

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: Tie to the theme of 'Good intentions misunderstood' â€” what situation requires you to be careful about how your actions are perceived this week?
tips: Consider a time when you intended to help someone but they misinterpreted your actions
Think about how you can be more intentional in your communication to avoid misunderstandings
Practically, this week, check in with a friend to see if your actions have been misunderstood

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray for understanding and humility in your relationships, and for God's guidance in how you respond to misunderstandings.
tips: Ask God to help you see others' perspectives before acting
Pray for the strength to forgive when others misunderstand you
Thank God for His protection and provision in the midst of conflicts

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read 2 Samuel 11:1-25 aloud, focusing on the emotional tension in David's actions and the dialogue about Uriah.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'I have seen' in David's thoughts (v.2, v.4)
Pay attention to the contrast between David's pride ('the king') and the humble Uriah's refusal (v.10-11)
The phrase 'the king's son' in v.13 shows David's attempt to cover up

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe who did what, where, and why in the events of David's sin with Bathsheba and the aftermath.
tips: Include David's initial sighting of Bathsheba on the roof (v.2-3)
Note David's command for Uriah to be sent to the front lines (v.15-17) and the result (v.18-25)
David's attempt to cover up by having Uriah killed (v.15-16)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: David's initial encounter with Bathsheba (v.2-3), Uriah's refusal to return home (v.10-11), or David's letter to Joab (v.15-16)?
tips: Uriah's response: 'the ark and Israel dwell in tents; Joab and my lord's servants camp in the open field' shows his loyalty and understanding of the military situation
David's command to 'put Uriah in the fiercest fighting' (v.15) reveals his calculated cruelty
The phrase 'I have seen the king' (v.1) in the context of David's sin shows his awareness of the gravity

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was the author (Samuel/Nathan/Gad) trying to communicate to Israel about the consequences of sin and power?
tips: David, the man after God's heart, falls into sin because of his pride and power
The passage shows that even the most righteous can sin when they abuse their authority
It foreshadows Christ who is sinless and redeems from sin

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The role of Joab, the meaning of 'the fiercest fighting', or the timing of Uriah's death?
tips: Joab's role: He is David's general and the one who carries out the command, showing the complexity of the king's power
'Fiercest fighting' in ancient warfare meant the most dangerous and deadly battle, which Joab would have to arrange
The passage does not explicitly state when Uriah dies, but it is implied that he dies in battle (v.18)

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you avoid the same sin of pride and cover-up as David in your relationships or decisions this week?
tips: Consider if you have a situation where you are trying to cover up a mistake or sin
Ask yourself: What would Uriah do in this situation? (loyalty to the cause and people)
Practice humility by confessing and seeking help before the problem gets worse

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray for the grace to confront sin and the strength to choose righteousness, like David's fall and redemption.
tips: Thank God for the truth that even David, the man after God's heart, fell in sin
Pray for the courage to confess mistakes and seek forgiveness
Ask God to help you avoid the temptation to cover up sin, as David did

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read 2 Samuel 13:1-39 aloud, focusing on the emotional shift from Amnon's initial request to Tamar to his later hatred.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'he' for Amnon showing his emotional transformation
Pay attention to Tamar's weeping and robe tearing (v. 19, 20) as signs of profound trauma
The phrase 'Come to me' (v. 10) demonstrates the manipulative nature of Amnon's request

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: Summarize WHO (Amnon, Tamar, Absalom, David) does WHAT (Amnon rapes Tamar, Absalom kills Amnon), WHERE (David's household), and WHY (Amnon's lust leading to revenge).
tips: Include Amnon's request for Tamar to prepare food (v. 10)
Note Tamar tearing her robe and weeping (v. 19, 20)
Highlight Absalom's calculated plan to kill Amnon at sheep-shearing (v. 28-30)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: Tamar's robe tearing (v. 19), Amnon's request (v. 10), or Absalom's words to Tamar (v. 20).
tips: Tamar's robe tearing symbolizes loss of virginity and status as a daughter of the king
Amnon's request in v. 10 shows manipulation and lack of respect for Tamar
Absalom's words in v. 20 reveal deep empathy and trauma while trying to protect Tamar

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Samuel/Nathan/Gad trying to communicate to Israel about the consequences of unaddressed sin?
tips: This passage shows how sin within families leads to devastating cycles of violence
David's passive anger demonstrates leadership failure when sin occurs in the household
The prophetic promise that 'the sword would not depart from David's house' (2 Samuel 12:10) is fulfilled through Absalom's revenge

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The cultural meaning of Tamar's robe tearing, Amnon's manipulative request, and Absalom's two-year wait.
tips: In ancient Israel, tearing a virgin daughter's robe was a sign of deep shame and mourning (v. 19)
Amnon's request to Tamar was a manipulation tactic to isolate her from others
Absalom waited two years to ensure Amnon was vulnerable before taking action (v. 28-30)

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you address unaddressed sin in your relationships this week?
tips: Consider a situation where someone has been hurt but you haven't spoken up
Practice telling the truth without escalating the situation like Tamar's initial response
Ask for the courage to forgive without revenge as Absalom did in his plan

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray specifically about breaking cycles of violence and seeking reconciliation.
tips: Thank God for Christ healing broken relationships (Romans 12:19-21)
Pray for strength to forgive without seeking revenge when hurt
Ask God to help you break the cycle of violence in your family and community

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read 2 Samuel 14:1-28 aloud, focusing on the wise woman's dialogue with David (vv. 1-12) and Absalom's demand to see the king (vv. 28-29).
tips: Notice the phrase 'I had two sons; one killed the other' (v. 2) - direct parallel to David's situation
Pay attention to David's emotional response: 'I have no son left' (v. 13) and his immediate action to send for Absalom (v. 14)
The barley field fire (v. 26) shows Absalom's anger and symbolic breaking of the relationship

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is involved, WHAT happens, WHERE it occurs, and WHY it matters for David and Absalom.
tips: Include the wise woman from Tekoa as the key intermediary
Note Absalom returns after two years of absence
Highlight David's initial refusal to see Absalom but eventual restoration

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the wise woman's parable (vv. 1-12), Absalom's demand to see the king (vv. 28-29), or David's immediate action to send for Absalom (v. 14)?
tips: The woman's parable is a powerful metaphor for David's situation: the banished son and the king's refusal to restore him
Absalom's bold move: demanding to see the king without being allowed to speak first (v. 28) shows his desperation
David's response: 'Bring back Absalom' (v. 14) shows swift decision once understanding occurs

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Samuel/Nathan/Gad trying to communicate to Israel through this passage about the restoration of Absalom?
tips: This passage emphasizes God's provision for restoration even in broken relationships
The wise woman's parable shows God's plan is to restore (like the ram in offering) rather than punish permanently
The key is banished people are not expelled forever because God has a way of restoring (as seen in Christ)

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The role of the wise woman, why David initially refuses to see Absalom, or the barley field fire?
tips: The wise woman's role: She is not a prophet but uses a parable to address the king's heart (v. 10)
David's initial refusal: He is under pressure from Joab and political tension (v. 13-14)
Barley field fire: Absalom sets it to show anger at Joab, symbolizing breaking relationship (v. 26)

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the theme of restoration (like Absalom's return) to your current situation this week?
tips: Consider a broken relationship that needs restoration (family, community, or friendship)
Think about what it would take to 'bring back' someone after a period of absence
Practice active listening and showing up like David's response to the wise woman

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray specifically about the theme of restoration in this passage
tips: Thank God for His provision in restoring broken relationships
Ask for wisdom to address the 'barley field' (unresolved conflicts) in your life
Pray for courage to see God (the king) and bow in submission like Absalom

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read 2 Samuel 15:1-37 aloud, paying attention to Absalom's dialogue at the gate (v.1-2) and the urgency in David's flight (v.24-25).
tips: Notice Absalom's declaration: 'if only I were judge!' (v.2)
Pay attention to the emotional weight of David's words: 'flee, or he will overtake us and strike the city with the sword' (v.26)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (Absalom and David), WHAT (the rebellion and David's flight), WHERE (Jerusalem and Hebron), and WHY (to take the throne).
tips: Absalom's secret plan to rally support by declaring himself king at Hebron
David's decision to flee Jerusalem after learning Israel's hearts have turned to Absalom (v.27)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: Absalom's manipulation of the people (v.1-2), David's trust in God's provision (v.28-29), or the ark being sent back (v.31-32)?
tips: Absalom's phrase 'if only I were judge!' (v.2) shows his desperation for authority
David's decision to send the ark back: 'if I find favor, God will bring me back to see it' (v.31) reveals his trust in God's ultimate will

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Samuel/Nathan/Gad trying to communicate to Israel through this passage?
tips: The passage shows that rebellion against God's anointed king (David) can lead to national destruction unless God intervenes
David's trust in God's sovereignty while fleeing (v.31) models the Christian response to persecution

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The role of Ahithophel, the meaning of 'stealing hearts', or David's decision to send the ark back?
tips: Ahithophel was David's trusted advisor but became Absalom's ally, showing how quickly loyalty can shift
'Stealing hearts' (v.12) refers to Absalom's political manipulation, not literal theft, but a cultural term for gaining popular support
The ark being sent back: This was a symbolic act of trust in God's provision, as the ark represents God's presence and covenant

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How does David's decision to send the ark back (v.31) apply to your life? What can you trust God to provide when you feel overwhelmed?
tips: When you feel like your life is in chaos, ask God to show you what to do
Like David, surrender your situation to God and trust His timing

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for His faithfulness in the midst of rebellion. Ask for courage to trust Him when your plans are disrupted.
tips: Thank God for providing a way out for David when he was trapped
Pray for strength to trust God's plan even when it seems like the rebellion is winning

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read 2 Samuel 17:1-23 aloud, focusing on the contrast between Ahithophel's and Hushai's plans in verses 1-7 and the dramatic hiding in the well (verses 15-16).
tips: Notice how Ahithophel's plan in verse 1-2 shows immediate strategic thinking
Listen for the tension in Hushai's counterproposal in verses 3-4
Pay attention to the emotional shift in verse 15-16 when the group hides

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: Identify the key strategic elements in Ahithophel's plan (verses 1-2) and compare with Hushai's alternative approach (verses 3-4).
tips: What specific military advantage did Ahithophel propose?
How did Hushai's plan address the weaknesses in Ahithophel's approach?
Why might King David have chosen Hushai's alternative despite the apparent urgency?

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: Examine the motivations behind Ahithophel's decision to advise King David to flee (verse 1) versus Hushai's decision to stay and advise (verse 3).
tips: What personal stakes might Ahithophel have had in the king's safety?
How did Hushai's position as a trusted advisor influence his decision?
What does this reveal about the relationship between advisors and the king?

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: Analyze how the group's decision to hide in the well (verse 15-16) reflects their relationship and trust levels.
tips: Why might they have chosen to hide rather than confront the enemy directly?
What does this reveal about their communication styles and risk tolerance?
How does this action impact their future strategic decisions?

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: Discuss the long-term consequences of Ahithophel's and Hushai's choices for King David's leadership and the kingdom.
tips: How did this event affect David's relationship with his advisors?
What lessons can be drawn about leadership in crisis situations?
How might these choices influence future conflicts or alliances?

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: What will you do about it? How will you apply this to your life?
tips: Be specific and practical
Think about this week

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together about what you've learned and your applications.
tips: Thank God for what you learned
Pray for each other

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read 2 Samuel 18:1-33 aloud, paying attention to the emotional weight of David's grief and the tragic events.
tips: Notice the phrase 'deal gently with young Absalom for my sake' (v. 3)
Pay attention to the description of the forest devours more than the sword (v. 10)
Notice David's lament: 'O my son Absalom, my son, my son Absalom!' (v. 33)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is involved, WHAT happens, WHERE it occurs, and WHY it matters.
tips: Include the battle in the forest of Ephraim
Note David's command to deal gently with Absalom (v. 3)
Describe the death of Absalom by Joab (v. 16-17) and David's reaction (v. 33)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: Absalom's death in the tree (v. 10), Joab's action (v. 16), or David's lament (v. 33)?
tips: The forest 'devours more than the sword' (v. 10) shows the devastating consequences of rebellion
Joab's decision to kill Absalom despite the king's command (v. 16) highlights the cost of rebellion
David's lament (v. 33) is the most poignant moment, showing the depth of his grief

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was the author trying to communicate to Israel about the consequences of rebellion and the importance of mercy?
tips: The author (Samuel) shows that rebellion has severe consequences (as seen in Absalom's death)
David's command to deal gently with Absalom (v. 3) was a call for mercy, but the reality of rebellion led to tragedy
The passage foreshadows the cost of sin and the need for God's mercy

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The role of Joab, the meaning of 'the forest devours more than the sword', and the armor-bearers' role?
tips: Joab disobeys the king's command to deal gently with Absalom (v. 3) because he saw Absalom as a threat to the kingdom
'The forest devours more than the sword' (v. 10) means the natural environment itself became a deadly trap in the battle
The ten armor-bearers (v. 17) were the personal guards of Absalom and they finished him, indicating the finality of his death

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you practice dealing gently with someone who has rebelled against you this week?
tips: Reflect on a situation where you felt you had to choose between your own desires and the commands of God (like David with Absalom)
Pray for the strength to forgive and show mercy, even when it is difficult

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray for the courage to forgive and deal gently with those who have rebelled against you, just as David did with Absalom.
tips: Ask God for the strength to carry the weight of grief when loved ones suffer
Pray for the grace to choose mercy over vengeance, even when it is hard

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read 2 Samuel 21:1-22 aloud, emphasizing the famine, blood guilt resolution, and Rizpah's vigil.
tips: Note the repetition of 'blood guilt' (vv. 2-6) and 'Saul's house' (vv. 2, 9)
Pay attention to the emotional weight of Rizpah guarding the bodies (v. 13)
Notice the shift from famine (v.1) to the resolution of the blood guilt (v.16)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, summarize WHO is involved, WHAT happens, WHERE it occurs, and WHY it matters for the land.
tips: Include the famine (3 years) and David's response to the LORD
Mention the Gibeonites' demand for seven from Saul's line and the execution
Note Rizpah's vigil and the burial of Saul and Jonathan's bones

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: Rizpah's vigil (v.13), the giants killed by David's men (v.25), or the blood guilt resolution (v.16)?
tips: Rizpah's vigil shows undying loyalty to the covenant, even when the bodies are left exposed
Jonathan's killing of the giant (v.25) is a powerful image of God's strength working through David's family
The resolution of the blood guilt (v.16) brings peace to the land, showing the importance of covenant restoration

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Samuel/Nathan/Gad trying to communicate to Israel through this passage about the covenant and blood guilt?
tips: The passage emphasizes that broken covenants require blood atonement, not just rituals
It shows that God's mercy can be extended through the right people (David) even after a leader (Saul) broke the covenant
The resolution of the blood guilt restores the land's blessing, demonstrating God's faithfulness to the covenant

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The blood guilt on Saul's house? The giants in Philistine wars? The Gibeonites' demand for seven?
tips: The term 'blood guilt' (Hebrew: 'tubah') refers to a specific covenant violation that requires atonement through blood, not just a moral failure
The Gibeonites' request for seven from Saul's line is unusual because Saul's line was already weakened by the famine and the murder of the Gibeonites
The giants (v.25) are a symbol of the Philistine threat, but their origin (descended from Rapha) is unclear in the text

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the lesson of Rizpah's vigil to your life this week? What is something you are holding onto that needs to be released?
tips: Like Rizpah, guard what is sacred (your faith, relationships) from being destroyed by the world
The blood guilt resolution shows that atonement requires specific steps (v.9-11) â€” what is the right step for your situation?
David's men swearing not to fight (v.23) is a lesson in leadership â€” when should you step back to protect others?

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together about the blood guilt resolution and the giants. Thank God for the atonement and ask for courage to face the giants (challenges) in your life.
tips: Thank God for providing the atonement through the blood of the covenant (v.16)
Pray for strength to be a Rizpah figure â€” guarding what is holy in your life
Ask God to help you face the 'giants' (challenges) that threaten your faith

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read 2 Samuel 22:1-51 aloud, focusing on the emotional tone and repetitive phrases of deliverance.
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'The LORD is my rock' (v.1-2)
Pay attention to the imagery of God as a warrior (v.11,12)
Note the shift from distress to victory in verses 14-16

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO David is singing to, WHAT God has done, WHERE and WHEN this occurred, and WHY David is singing.
tips: David was delivered from Saul and his enemies (v.1-2)
The song is composed after a battle or crisis (v.14-16)
David's purpose is to give thanks for God's deliverance and to proclaim God's faithfulness to his line

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the description of God as rock (v.1-2), God's intervention (v.11-12), or David's declaration of God's delight (v.16).
tips: The phrase 'He parted the heavens and came down' (v.11) shows God's power and immediacy of intervention
David's statement 'He rescued me because He delighted in me' (v.16) emphasizes God's personal love and choice
The image of God drawing David from 'many waters' (v.14) conveys deliverance from deep trouble

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was David trying to communicate to the people of Israel about God through this song?
tips: David emphasizes God as the Rock who delivers and protects (v.1-2)
This song points to God's active intervention in history (v.11-12) and His steadfast love for David's line (v.50)
The authorial purpose is to show that God is the ultimate deliverer and that His covenant with David (and by extension, Christ) is secure

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The imagery of God as a warrior, the phrase 'many waters', or the concept of God's delight?
tips: 'He rode upon a cherub' (v.11) uses an angelic imagery that may be unfamiliar; cherubim are heavenly beings, not physical entities
'Many waters' (v.14) could refer to the overwhelming enemies or the deep spiritual crisis David faced
The phrase 'He delighted in me' (v.16) suggests a personal, covenantal love that might be hard to grasp in a modern context

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: David declares God as his rock and deliverer. What situation in your life requires you to trust God as your rock this week?
tips: Think about a time when you felt overwhelmed (like 'many waters') and God delivered you
Pray for courage to rely on God as your rock in a current struggle
Practice stepping away from your problems and trusting God's deliverance (like David did after being rescued)

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for being your rock and deliverer. Ask for the courage to trust Him in your current struggles.
tips: Thank God for delivering you from your enemies (spiritual, emotional, or physical) like David was delivered
Pray for God to be your rock and fortress in your current trials
Ask God to show you His deliverance through Christ, the ultimate Rock

chapters.chapterTitle: David's Last Words; His Mighty Men

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read 2 Samuel 23:1-39 aloud, focusing on the phrase 'The Spirit of the LORD spoke through me' (v.1-2) and the description of the just ruler (v.3-4).
tips: Notice the repetition of 'the God of Israel' in v.2
Pay attention to the contrast between David's security and the Philistine threat in v.13-14
Note the list of the Thirty warriors (v.18-39) as a testament to David's leadership

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (David) does WHAT (proclaims his last words and honors his mighty men), WHERE (in the context of David's rule in Israel), and WHY (to establish the security of his house through God's covenant).
tips: Include the three metaphors for the just ruler (v.3-4)
Note the three mighty men who broke through the Philistine garrison (v.13-14)
Describe the Thirty warriors and the inclusion of Uriah the Hittite (v.18-39)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: David's description of the just ruler (v.3-4), the three mighty men breaking through the Philistine garrison (v.13-14), or the covenant of David's house (v.5).
tips: The just ruler imagery is profound and connects to Christ (the Light of the World)
The three men's feat shows David's trust in God's provision for his warriors
The covenant promise in v.5 is a powerful reminder of God's faithfulness to David's line

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Samuel/Nathan/Gad trying to communicate to Israel through this passage about David's rule and covenant?
tips: David's rule is secure because of God's everlasting covenant (v.5)
The just ruler who rules in the fear of God brings life and prosperity (v.3-4)
The mighty men are a sign of God's provision for David's kingdom

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The phrase 'anointed of Israel's God', the three metaphors for the just ruler, and the specific roles of the mighty men.
tips: 'Anointed' refers to David's kingship, which was consecrated by God (not self-appointed)
The three metaphors (light, sun, rain) illustrate the just ruler's effectiveness: clarity, life-giving, and abundance
The 'Three' and 'Thirty' are specific groups of David's warriors, with the Thirty being the elite force that includes Uriah the Hittite

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you live in the security of God's covenant (like David's house) this week?
tips: Reflect on how you can rule your life with integrity and fear of God, as David's just ruler
Consider the covenant promise and how it gives you security in God's provision
Ask God to help you be part of a community that breaks through obstacles (like the mighty men)

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray for God's covenant security and the strength to be a just ruler.
tips: Thank God for the promise of an everlasting covenant with David's house
Pray for the courage to rule with integrity and fear of God in your daily life
Ask God to help you be part of His mighty army that breaks through obstacles

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read 2 Samuel 24:1-24 aloud, paying attention to the emotional shift from David's initial sinfulness to his costly obedience.
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'I have sinned greatly' (v. 9)
Pay attention to David's internal conflict: 'I will not offer the LORD what cost me nothing' (v. 20)
The emotional weight of the plague: 70,000 dying in three days (v. 14)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (David, Joab, Gad, Araunah, Israel/Judah) did WHAT (census, choosing plague, buying the threshing floor) WHERE (Israel and Judah, Araunah's threshing floor in Jerusalem) and WHY (God's anger against Israel, the sin of the census).
tips: Include the 9-month delay in the census (v. 2-3)
Note David's immediate remorse after the census (v. 8-9)
Describe the three choices Gad offers (v. 10-11)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: David's realization of sin (v. 9), Gad's three choices (v. 10-11), or David's refusal to take the land for free (v. 20).
tips: David's confession: 'I have sinned greatly' shows deep humility
The tension in Gad's choices: famine, flight, plague (plague being the most direct and severe)
David's refusal: 'I will not offer the LORD what cost me nothing' demonstrates costly obedience

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was the prophet Gad trying to communicate to Israel about God's character and response to sin?
tips: The passage shows God's mercy: He relents from the plague (v. 17)
The cost of sin: David's sin led to a severe judgment (plague) but God provided a way of redemption
The temple site: Araunah's threshing floor becomes the future temple (v. 18-24) for the people to worship God

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The reason for the census, the three choices of judgment, and the significance of the threshing floor.
tips: The census was not a sin in itself, but David's motivation (to have a census for military strength) was a sin against God's will (v. 1-2)
The three choices: famine (7 years), flight (3 months), plague (3 days) â€” God's judgment was the most immediate but severe
The threshing floor of Araunah: It was a common place for grain processing, but God chose it to be the temple site (v. 16-17)

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: David's costly sacrifice of 50 shekels to buy the land for God's temple â€” what area of your life requires you to pay a price for God's purposes this week?
tips: Consider an area where you're holding back from full obedience
Think about something you can 'buy' for God (like time, resources, or freedom)
How can you practice David's humility and costly obedience in small steps?

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for His mercy in the face of sin. Ask for the courage to make costly sacrifices for His kingdom.
tips: Thank God for the plague that was stopped (v. 17)
Pray for humility when you face sin
Ask God to help you buy a piece of land (a sacrifice) for His kingdom
